Apple___Apple_scab.disease_symptoms: Dark, olive-green spots appear on leaves and fruits, which may become deformed or drop early.
Apple___Apple_scab.organic_treatment: Remove infected leaves and fruit from the tree and ground. Apply neem oil or sulfur sprays during early growth stages.
Apple___Apple_scab.inorganic_treatment: Use fungicides like captan or myclobutanil during the pre-flowering and fruit set stages.
Apple___Apple_scab.preventive_measure: Plant resistant apple varieties and ensure good air circulation by pruning branches.
Apple___Apple_scab.conclusion: Timely removal of infected parts and preventive fungicide use can manage apple scab effectively.

Apple___Black_rot.disease_symptoms: Dark, sunken spots on fruits that expand over time. Leaves may show brown spots with purple edges.
Apple___Black_rot.organic_treatment: Prune infected branches and remove fallen fruits. Use compost tea or organic copper sprays to protect healthy parts.
Apple___Black_rot.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides like thiophanate-methyl or copper-based products early in the season.
Apple___Black_rot.preventive_measure: Clean up fallen leaves and fruits. Avoid wounding the fruits during handling.
Apple___Black_rot.conclusion: Maintaining orchard hygiene and applying fungicides early can prevent severe losses.

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.disease_symptoms: Bright orange or rust-colored spots on leaves and fruits. Can cause leaf drop and fruit deformation.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.organic_treatment: Remove nearby cedar trees or prune galls from them. Spray apple trees with sulfur-based fungicides.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.inorganic_treatment: Use fungicides like myclobutanil or propiconazole during early leaf development.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.preventive_measure: Avoid planting apples near junipers or cedar trees. Plant resistant apple varieties.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.conclusion: Early action and maintaining a safe distance from cedar trees can control this disease.

Apple___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy apple trees have green leaves, firm fruits, and show no signs of spots or discoloration.
Apple___healthy.organic_treatment: Maintain soil fertility with compost. Water trees regularly and ensure proper pruning for air circulation.
Apple___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use balanced fertilizers for optimal growth if necessary.
Apple___healthy.preventive_measure: Regularly inspect for pests or diseases and act quickly. Avoid overcrowding of trees.
Apple___healthy.conclusion: Healthy practices lead to strong and productive apple trees.

Blueberry___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy blueberry bushes have vibrant green leaves, firm berries, and no signs of wilting or discoloration.
Blueberry___healthy.organic_treatment: Apply mulch to retain soil moisture and keep roots cool. Use compost or organic fertilizers to nourish plants.
Blueberry___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Apply slow-release fertilizers if needed for better yield.
Blueberry___healthy.preventive_measure: Ensure proper drainage and plant in acidic soil. Regularly check for pests or diseases.
Blueberry___healthy.conclusion: Proper care and maintenance result in a productive and healthy blueberry crop.

Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.disease_symptoms: A white powdery coating appears on leaves, buds, and young fruits. Leaves may curl, and growth can be stunted.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.organic_treatment: Spray a solution of baking soda (1 teaspoon) and water (1 liter) on the affected areas. Use neem oil for early treatment.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.inorganic_treatment: Apply sulfur-based or potassium bicarbonate fungicides during early infection.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.preventive_measure: Ensure proper air circulation by pruning. Avoid excessive use of nitrogen fertilizers.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.conclusion: With early detection and proper sprays, powdery mildew can be controlled effectively.

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy cherry trees have lush green leaves, healthy fruit, and no visible signs of disease such as spots, wilting, or deformities.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.organic_treatment: Maintain good soil health with organic compost, and use neem oil or insecticidal soap to prevent pest infestations.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Apply balanced fertilizers to support strong growth, and treat with fungicides like copper-based products if any disease signs appear.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.preventive_measure: Ensure proper spacing between trees for air circulation, regularly prune to remove any dead or diseased wood, and monitor for pests.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.conclusion: Healthy cherry trees thrive with proper care, regular monitoring for pests, and good cultural practices, ensuring high-quality fruit production.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.disease_symptoms: Small, rectangular gray or tan spots form on leaves, eventually merging and causing leaf death.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.organic_treatment: Remove infected leaves and crop debris. Use compost tea as a preventive spray.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin or pyraclostrobin early in the season.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.preventive_measure: Rotate crops yearly and avoid planting corn in the same field. Use resistant corn varieties.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.conclusion: Timely removal of infected material and fungicide application protect the crop.

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.disease_symptoms: Reddish-brown pustules appear on both sides of leaves and sometimes on stalks, weakening the plant.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.organic_treatment: Encourage good airflow by spacing plants properly. Apply sprays like neem oil early.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.inorganic_treatment: Use fungicides such as tebuconazole or azoxystrobin for control.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.preventive_measure: Plant resistant corn varieties and maintain good crop rotation practices.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust.conclusion: Managing rust early and maintaining good farming practices can ensure a healthy yield.

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.disease_symptoms: Large, grayish-brown, cigar-shaped lesions appear on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and yield.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.organic_treatment: Remove infected leaves and crop debris. Use natural sprays like garlic or onion extract.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides such as mancozeb or chlorothalonil as soon as symptoms appear.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.preventive_measure: Plant resistant hybrids and rotate crops. Avoid overwatering the plants.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.conclusion: Early treatment and resistant varieties are key to controlling Northern Leaf Blight.

Corn_(maize)___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy corn plants have green, upright leaves with no discoloration or lesions. Stalks are strong, and ears are well-formed.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.organic_treatment: Use organic compost to enrich the soil. Water the plants evenly and avoid waterlogging.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use balanced fertilizers with appropriate nitrogen levels for better growth.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.preventive_measure: Inspect plants regularly for pests or diseases and act quickly if problems arise. Practice crop rotation.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.conclusion: Proper care, balanced nutrients, and timely observation keep corn plants healthy.

Grape___Black_rot.disease_symptoms: Brown circular spots appear on leaves with black fruiting bodies in the center. Fruits develop dark, shriveled areas, turning black and mummified.
Grape___Black_rot.organic_treatment: Prune and remove infected leaves and fruits. Spray with neem oil or compost tea to prevent spread.
Grape___Black_rot.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides like myclobutanil or captan at the first sign of disease.
Grape___Black_rot.preventive_measure: Plant resistant grape varieties and maintain good air circulation by spacing vines properly.
Grape___Black_rot.conclusion: Early pruning and regular sprays can protect your vineyard from severe losses.

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).disease_symptoms: Dark streaks appear on leaves, and fruits show sunken, discolored spots. Over time, plants may show stunted growth.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected plant parts. Apply compost or organic fertilizers to strengthen the plant.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).inorganic_treatment: Use systemic fungicides such as tebuconazole for managing the disease.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).preventive_measure: Avoid wounding the vines during pruning. Ensure proper drainage and air circulation.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).conclusion: Regular care and avoiding vine injury are essential to prevent Esca.

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.disease_symptoms: Brown or black spots form on the leaves, often surrounded by a yellow halo. Severe cases may lead to leaf drop.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves. Use a garlic spray or neem oil to reduce spread.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides like mancozeb or captan to protect healthy leaves.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.preventive_measure: Keep vineyards well-pruned and remove fallen leaves to reduce infection sources.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.conclusion: Timely removal of infected leaves and preventive fungicide application are key.

Grape___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy grapevines have green, vibrant leaves with no spots or discoloration. Fruits are firm and well-formed.
Grape___healthy.organic_treatment: Provide compost to enrich the soil. Water the vines regularly but avoid waterlogging.
Grape___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use balanced fertilizers with micronutrients like potassium for better growth.
Grape___healthy.preventive_measure: Prune the vines for better airflow and regularly check for early signs of pests or diseases.
Grape___healthy.conclusion: Good vineyard management practices ensure healthy growth and high yield.

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).disease_symptoms: Yellowing of leaves, misshapen fruits, and stunted growth. Fruits often taste bitter and remain green.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).organic_treatment: Use neem oil or organic insecticides to control the psyllid population that spreads the disease.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).inorganic_treatment: Apply systemic insecticides like imidacloprid to control psyllids effectively.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).preventive_measure: Plant disease-free saplings and regularly inspect for psyllids. Remove infected trees to prevent spread.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).conclusion: Early detection and psyllid control are crucial to managing Citrus Greening.

Peach___Bacterial_spot.disease_symptoms: Small, dark spots on leaves that enlarge and turn into irregular, greasy lesions. Fruits may develop sunken, scabby spots.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.organic_treatment: Apply copper-based sprays or organic bactericides like Serenade. Remove and destroy infected plant material.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.inorganic_treatment: Use copper fungicides like copper hydroxide during early stages of the disease.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.preventive_measure: Plant resistant varieties and avoid overhead irrigation. Ensure good airflow by proper pruning.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.conclusion: Managing bacterial spot involves early treatment and maintaining hygienic orchard practices.

Peach___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy peach trees have vibrant green leaves without any spots or lesions. Fruits develop uniformly without blemishes.
Peach___healthy.organic_treatment: Use compost or organic fertilizers to promote healthy growth. Ensure the soil is well-drained.
Peach___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Apply balanced NPK fertilizers as needed for optimal growth and fruiting.
Peach___healthy.preventive_measure: Inspect trees regularly and prune to maintain good air circulation. Remove weeds and debris around the base.
Peach___healthy.conclusion: Good soil management and timely pruning keep peach trees healthy and productive.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.disease_symptoms: Small, water-soaked spots appear on leaves and fruits, enlarging into dark, irregular lesions. Leaves may drop prematurely.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.organic_treatment: Spray neem oil or garlic extract early to control bacterial spread. Remove infected leaves.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.inorganic_treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides or antibiotics like streptomycin for effective control.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.preventive_measure: Use disease-free seeds and avoid overhead irrigation. Practice crop rotation.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.conclusion: Early control of bacterial spots ensures healthy pepper plants and a good yield.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy pepper plants have green, smooth leaves and firm fruits without blemishes.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.organic_treatment: Enrich soil with organic compost and provide consistent watering.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use balanced fertilizers with adequate potassium and phosphorus.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.preventive_measure: Inspect plants regularly for early signs of pests or diseases. Provide adequate spacing for air circulation.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.conclusion: With proper care, bell pepper plants stay healthy and yield high-quality fruits.

Potato___Early_blight.disease_symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings appear on older leaves. Leaves may yellow and die, reducing tuber size.
Potato___Early_blight.organic_treatment: Apply neem oil or a solution of baking soda and water to infected plants.
Potato___Early_blight.inorganic_treatment: Use fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb as soon as symptoms appear.
Potato___Early_blight.preventive_measure: Practice crop rotation and avoid planting potatoes in the same soil consecutively. Remove infected plant debris.
Potato___Early_blight.conclusion: Early detection and proper fungicide application help in managing early blight effectively.

Potato___Late_blight.disease_symptoms: Large, irregular dark brown spots with pale green borders appear on leaves. Plants may wilt, and tubers can rot.
Potato___Late_blight.organic_treatment: Use copper-based fungicides or homemade sprays with baking soda and water. Remove infected plant material immediately.
Potato___Late_blight.inorganic_treatment: Apply systemic fungicides like metalaxyl or mefenoxam during early stages of disease.
Potato___Late_blight.preventive_measure: Ensure good air circulation around plants, avoid overhead watering, and remove infected plant debris.
Potato___Late_blight.conclusion: Late blight can devastate a potato crop, but early detection and regular fungicide application can minimize damage.

Potato___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy potato plants have vibrant green leaves, strong stems, and smooth, firm tubers.
Potato___healthy.organic_treatment: Provide well-drained soil, enrich it with compost, and water regularly to promote strong growth.
Potato___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use balanced fertilizers with adequate nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium to support healthy growth.
Potato___healthy.preventive_measure: Inspect plants regularly, control pests, and maintain proper soil conditions.
Potato___healthy.conclusion: Healthy potato plants require good soil management, pest control, and proper irrigation to thrive.

Raspberry___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy raspberry plants have green, vibrant leaves with no signs of wilting or discoloration. The fruits are firm and ripe.
Raspberry___healthy.organic_treatment: Use organic compost and mulch to enrich the soil. Water consistently but avoid over-watering.
Raspberry___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Fertilize with a balanced, slow-release fertilizer for continuous nutrient supply.
Raspberry___healthy.preventive_measure: Prune regularly to improve air circulation and remove dead wood.
Raspberry___healthy.conclusion: Healthy raspberry plants benefit from proper care, including regular pruning and appropriate watering practices.

Soybean___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy soybean plants show lush, green leaves and strong stems. There are no yellowing or wilting signs.
Soybean___healthy.organic_treatment: Add organic compost to the soil to enhance fertility. Ensure proper soil drainage to avoid waterlogging.
Soybean___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use a balanced fertilizer with adequate nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium to support growth.
Soybean___healthy.preventive_measure: Rotate crops and maintain proper spacing to avoid pests and disease buildup.
Soybean___healthy.conclusion: Soybean plants thrive with balanced nutrition, proper spacing, and consistent watering.

Squash___Powdery_mildew.disease_symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth appears on the leaves, followed by yellowing and leaf drop. Affects plant growth.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.organic_treatment: Spray with a mixture of baking soda and water or neem oil to control the spread of the fungus.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.inorganic_treatment: Use fungicides containing sulfur or potassium bicarbonate to control the fungus.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.preventive_measure: Provide good air circulation by spacing plants properly and remove infected leaves immediately.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.conclusion: Preventive measures and early treatment can control powdery mildew and prevent damage to squash crops.

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.disease_symptoms: Yellow or brown spots appear along the edges of leaves, which may then curl or dry out. Severe cases lead to leaf drop.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.organic_treatment: Use compost teas or neem oil to help control the spread of the disease. Remove infected leaves regularly.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides containing copper or sulfur to treat the infected plants.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.preventive_measure: Ensure good air circulation around the plants and avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity around the leaves.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.conclusion: Leaf scorch can be managed by maintaining proper plant care, including timely removal of affected leaves and preventing water stress.

Strawberry___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy strawberry plants have vibrant green leaves with no discoloration. The fruit develops evenly and remains firm.
Strawberry___healthy.organic_treatment: Use organic fertilizers like compost and mulch to maintain soil moisture and fertility.
Strawberry___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use a balanced fertilizer rich in potassium to encourage strong growth and fruiting.
Strawberry___healthy.preventive_measure: Mulch around the plants to keep the roots cool and prevent weed growth. Prune regularly to allow good air circulation.
Strawberry___healthy.conclusion: Healthy strawberries require well-drained soil, consistent watering, and regular maintenance to prevent pests and diseases.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.disease_symptoms: Small, water-soaked spots with a yellow halo appear on the leaves. Spots may merge, causing extensive leaf damage.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.organic_treatment: Spray with copper-based fungicides or use homemade garlic or neem oil sprays for control.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.inorganic_treatment: Apply copper sulfate or other copper-based bactericides to control the bacterial spread.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.preventive_measure: Avoid overhead watering, use disease-resistant varieties, and remove infected plant material immediately.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.conclusion: Bacterial spot can be controlled by using proper treatments and preventing the spread through hygiene and careful management.

Tomato___Early_blight.disease_symptoms: Dark, concentric rings appear on older leaves, which turn yellow and die. Early blight leads to defoliation, affecting fruit production.
Tomato___Early_blight.organic_treatment: Use neem oil or a mixture of baking soda and water to prevent fungal spread. Remove infected leaves promptly.
Tomato___Early_blight.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb to control the infection.
Tomato___Early_blight.preventive_measure: Ensure proper spacing between plants, remove plant debris, and practice crop rotation to avoid recurrence.
Tomato___Early_blight.conclusion: Early blight can significantly reduce yields, but early intervention and good crop management practices help prevent damage.

Tomato___Late_blight.disease_symptoms: Dark, irregular lesions appear on leaves and stems, with a white, fuzzy growth on the underside. Fruits may rot and turn mushy.
Tomato___Late_blight.organic_treatment: Use copper-based fungicides or neem oil to manage late blight. Remove and destroy infected plant material.
Tomato___Late_blight.inorganic_treatment: Apply systemic fungicides like metalaxyl or mefenoxam for more effective control of the disease.
Tomato___Late_blight.preventive_measure: Avoid waterlogging and practice crop rotation to prevent the buildup of the disease. Remove any infected plants promptly.
Tomato___Late_blight.conclusion: Late blight is a serious disease that requires quick action to protect tomato crops, including timely fungicide use and proper plant care.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.disease_symptoms: Yellowish patches appear on the upper leaf surfaces, with a white, fuzzy mold on the underside. Leaves eventually turn brown and fall off.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.organic_treatment: Spray with neem oil or a mixture of water and baking soda to control fungal growth.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.inorganic_treatment: Use copper-based fungicides to treat affected plants and prevent further spread of the disease.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.preventive_measure: Provide adequate spacing between plants for good air circulation, and avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.conclusion: Leaf mold can severely damage tomato plants, but early detection and effective treatment can minimize crop loss.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.disease_symptoms: Small, dark brown to black spots with concentric rings appear on the leaves. The leaves turn yellow and may drop prematurely.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.organic_treatment: Use a solution of neem oil or baking soda with water to reduce the spread of fungal spores.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.inorganic_treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides to control the disease and protect healthy plant tissue.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.preventive_measure: Practice crop rotation, remove infected leaves immediately, and avoid working with plants when wet to reduce fungal spread.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.conclusion: Septoria leaf spot can reduce tomato yields, but proper care and timely fungicide treatments can help manage the disease.

Tomato___Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider.disease_symptoms: Leaves show stippling (small white or yellow spots), and webbing may appear on plants. Leaves eventually turn yellow and may fall off.
Tomato___Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider.organic_treatment: Use insecticidal soap or neem oil to control spider mites. Introduce predatory mites as natural pest control.
Tomato___Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider.inorganic_treatment: Apply miticides containing chemicals like abamectin or chlorfenapyr to target the mites.
Tomato___Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider.preventive_measure: Maintain good plant hygiene, control dust, and avoid over-watering to minimize mite populations.
Tomato___Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider.conclusion: Spider mites can cause significant damage to tomato plants if not controlled, but early action can prevent widespread infestation.

Tomato___Target_Spot.disease_symptoms: Round, dark brown spots with concentric rings appear on the leaves. Infected leaves turn yellow and eventually fall off.
Tomato___Target_Spot.organic_treatment: Use neem oil or sulfur-based fungicides to reduce the spread of the fungus.
Tomato___Target_Spot.inorganic_treatment: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb to control the disease.
Tomato___Target_Spot.preventive_measure: Provide proper spacing for plants, remove infected leaves, and avoid wetting the leaves during watering.
Tomato___Target_Spot.conclusion: Target spot can damage tomato plants, but with good cultural practices and timely fungicide treatments, it can be controlled.

Tomato___Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.disease_symptoms: Yellowing of the leaves, stunted growth, and curling of the leaves. Affected plants may also show reduced fruit production.
Tomato___Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.organic_treatment: There are no effective organic treatments for this virus. Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent spread.
Tomato___Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.inorganic_treatment: There are no chemical treatments for the virus. Control is best through management of vector pests like whiteflies.
Tomato___Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.preventive_measure: Use insect nets to protect plants from insect vectors, and remove any infected plants promptly.
Tomato___Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.conclusion: Yellow leaf curl virus is challenging to manage, but preventing vector insects and early removal of infected plants can help control its spread.

Tomato___Mosaic_virus.disease_symptoms: Mosaic patterns of light and dark green appear on the leaves, and plants may exhibit stunted growth and reduced fruit quality.
Tomato___Mosaic_virus.organic_treatment: There are no effective organic treatments for this virus. Control is primarily through managing insect vectors and removing infected plants.
Tomato___Mosaic_virus.inorganic_treatment: There are no chemical treatments for the virus. Control relies on removing infected plants and controlling aphid populations.
Tomato___Mosaic_virus.preventive_measure: Use virus-resistant varieties, avoid handling infected plants, and control aphid populations to reduce virus spread.
Tomato___Mosaic_virus.conclusion: Mosaic virus can severely affect tomato crops, but by removing infected plants and controlling aphids, the spread of the virus can be minimized.

Tomato___healthy.disease_symptoms: Healthy tomato plants have bright green leaves, sturdy stems, and the fruit ripens uniformly with no discoloration or blemishes.
Tomato___healthy.organic_treatment: Feed plants with compost and organic fertilizers to ensure healthy growth. Water regularly and provide good drainage.
Tomato___healthy.inorganic_treatment: Use balanced fertilizers and ensure plants receive adequate nutrients for strong growth and fruiting.
Tomato___healthy.preventive_measure: Practice crop rotation, ensure proper spacing for air circulation, and monitor for pests and diseases regularly.
Tomato___healthy.conclusion: Healthy tomato plants require good care, including proper soil management, regular watering, and pest control to produce high-quality fruits.
